content:
This is quite tough for Reverse.

It's not really reverse-engineerable from the test cases.

I got it in Reverse and got 100% on test cases with the below Ruby code:
a = gets.chomp
b = gets.chomp
puts b.tr("^a-zA-z","").chars.uniq.count{!a.include?(_1)}

I basically just checked how many unique letters in b were not in a. This passes all of the test cases, but gets just 71% on the validators.

A reverse clash really needs to have very well defined tests and validators for it to be solvable in Reverse.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Too difficult

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: little difficut

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Might be quite difficult in reverse mode.

* Please be consistent with your variable names.
- You use "A" and "B" in the explanation in Goal section.
- You use "a" and "b" in the example in Goal section and in the stub generator.
- You use "string1" and "string2" in Input section.

* I don't think you need to put an example in Goal section because (1) it is almost a repeat of the example shown a little bit further below and does not really add much, and (2) it is not formatted well.

* Please follow the example in the contribution guidelines to present Input and Output sections e.g. including line numbers and variable types.
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement#guidelines

* Constraints: Suggest to delete "also".

* Cases: Tests and validators should be different.

* I also suggest to have a case where the first string is shorter than the second.

Thanks.
As mentioned, please add line numbers in the Input and Output section. Thanks.
